subject: Home & DIY
title: When Chairs Were Thrones
description: Learn When Chairs Were Thrones in one minute.

hook.text: For most of history, sitting in a chair meant you were in charge. Everyone else stood, squatted, or sat on the floor.

buildup.text: In medieval Europe, only the lord of a household had a chair. His wife got a stool. Guests sat on benches.

discovery.text: The word 'chairman' literally means 'the person who sits in the chair'â€”the one with authority.

twist.text: Chairs became common only in the 1600s when mass production in wood-turning made them affordable for the middle class.

climax.text: Today we sit in chairs 8+ hours daily. For 99% of human history, people barely sat in them at all.

punchline.text: The chair was a status symbol, not furniture.

quiz.question: Where does the title 'chairman' originate?
options: From the person who had the authority to sit in the chair
From a chair-making guild in medieval England
From a specific throne in Parliament
